title: ChiBitCTy
author: ChiBitCTy
created_time: February 12, 2025, 12:46:29 AMLast edit: February 12, 2025, 10:17:01 PM by ChiBitCTy
content: I run an extremely large retirement plan here in the United States (well, I am the sole advisor on it).  I got asked the other day during a large presentation I was putting on, if you could give a young investor one piece of advice, what would it be.  What immediately came to mind "never listen to your friends, family or co-worker when it comes to investment advice.  If I had a penny for every bit of piss poor information I've heard one co-worker tell the next or uncle tell his nephew or whatever, I would be a filthy rich man.  Why do I bring this up?  A buddy of mine whom I love to death, as nice as I can possibly say, is an idiot.  Two summers ago we went to the Nelly Ja Rule concert together and someone brought up bitcoin, he said "oh that's a scam".  Knowing full well he knows NOTHING about cryptocurrency or finances ..I didn't even hit him with the "ok so bitcoin is a scam, fair enough, what's the blockchain?" NO ONE has ever been able to explain that who's told me bitcoin is a scam.   I just told him it's not.  He's knows I'm an FA and pretty sure he knew I was pretty "deeply" involved in the bitcoin community.  He texts me today "do you know anything about bitcoin" , well last night.  I said in fact yeah, I know quite a bit.  I asked why "A friend told me I should buy some".  I sent him a voice message back ... "Sean, I'm a huge bitcoin supporter, I've been around for over a decade now and truly fell in love with it for the tech.  But here's the thing, it's inherently NOT an investment, and you shouldn't consider it until you get your finances straight. He has NOTHING to his name.  He just for the first time in his 40 plus year life got a decent job.  I know he doesn't know how to properly bank even (credit unions for check, online banks for savings...AVOID the big banks like BOA, Chase, Wells Fargo etc).  I also know he doesn't have knickle in any "backbone investments".  What I mean buy that is your long term financial plans.  401k's, IRA's etc.  I said once you get that on track, then sure I think you should probably put a few bucks in to it, but until then.This is a reminder that your friends likely don't know jack shit about investing, and seek advice from a licensed professional, not some jerk off co-worker who tells everyone to do the same thing even though everyone's situation is different.Let's not forget bitcoin is NOT a replacement for traditional finances.  A write up both myself and Greg Maxwell contributed to heavily.  Greg is cypherpunk, he sits at the table with best of the best in the "game"...so no need to take my word for it.  https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5288768.0As always, my DMs are open.  I'm willing to help provide guidance.  I will never ask for a fn cent.  It's my passion helping people (more so animals, but people too lol).  I've offered my services many times here before and I think ONE person has taken me up on it.  I'm a 20 year FA, Series 6, 7, 63, 65, life, health, CRC licensed.  I'm no fool, take advantage of free help.  But my main stressor is don't be dumb, set your foundation first,then buy bitcoin.

comments.body: Sure you've done well with your offers! Apparently, co-workers, Friends and family often only suggest and/or gives advise to anyone who they think needs it specifically on what they either regret not investing in or what they wish to invest in even though they are obviously limited in knowledge of (whatsoever investment) the invest they sure will offer you without any considerations. And of course I wouldn't also gree 100% percent that one shouldn't take the advise of co-workers friends and family because sometimes this friends and family could be you @OP with all the in-depth knowledge hence saying one shouldn't take such advise might equally mean your relatives friends should disregard your advise "if all things being equal"

comments.author: Darker45
comments.body: I guess a prevalent problem among many Bitcoin or crypto investors is premature investing. For example, many eagerly jumped right into Bitcoin without knowing the basics and the implications. For one, many went into it even if they aren't patient enough to withstand boredom hodling for years. They had no idea Bitcoin is basically a long-term investment. Many of them even bought at the top. Also, many didn't educate themselves with the basics of the technology. In the end, they either sold below their buying price because they badly needed the money or lost it because they took a pic of their backup phrase and kept it in their phones. So, I definitely agree to "set your foundation first, then buy Bitcoin." Or perhaps Bitcoin might not be for you.

comments.author: Apocollapse
comments.body: I would say your strategy are correct for Average Joe, because most people can't take risk.The most important investment that must people get first is health investment, make sure to have health insurance even it's the cheapest program.Next, have emergency funds for 6-12 months monthly spending.After that, it depend on us what are the investment we want to invest.Most people like to invest in debt securities, mutual funds or any investments that can give guaranteed profit like 4%-8%. They think if the return is higher than inflation rate released by central bank, they're in profit. Like, if the inflation rate is 4%, they're making 3% per year if the return is 7%. But, the real inflation rate is actually around 10% per year.It's really hard to find investment that pays higher 10% per year, Bitcoin is the solution and it's the lowest risk for me compared to business, low cap stock, and P2P lending.

comments.author: Alpha Marine
comments.body: Pretty solid advice here actually. I just disagree with something.While I don't know your friend at all, you obviously know him better than me, I don't think he needs to have all the things you mentioned before he puts money into Bitcoin. A better advice would have been for him to learn about Bitcoin and understand it before he could put money into it. If after understanding bitcoin, he still wants to invest in it, then fine, but he shouldn't do it because a college or whoever said he should do it. Also taking financial advice from relatives who actually know what they're talking about ain't a bad thing as long as you do your own research. You for example are a financial analyst and you probably have relatives or friends or nephews, you've have decades of experience so you definitely know what you're talking about when you give financial advice, so if the person giving the advice is like that then I don't think its wrong to take it seriously. All you have to do is do your own research and seek a second or even third opinion if you have to. I don't think you have to have your life or finances in order first before buying bitcoin. As long as you know and understand what bitcoin is, and have a source of income where you also have enough disposable income, you can buy bitcoin by DCAing if you want to.

comments.author: kryptqnick
comments.body: To me, an advice would be precisely how the op explained why he didn't encourage his friend to invest: Get your financial situation straight and stable first, consider buying Bitcoin later. Bitcoin is volatile, buying it is a risk, and people shouldn't risk what they can't afford to lose.Now, if a person can earn Bitcoin, that's a different story, but there should again be an understanding that basic needs come first, saving up this BTC comes second.

comments.author: OgNasty
comments.body: The best piece of advice I can think of for a young investor is to, "get off zero." So many people are afraid to invest or they think they need a wizard to help them do it.  Nothing teaches like experience.  Just get off zero, get yourself some skin in the game, and that's when you start learning.  There are so many little nuances in investing and trying to learn without doing makes things far more difficult.  The sooner people toss a couple bucks at an investment, the sooner they can get comfortable with seeing how it reacts to different situations.  Investing doesn't have to be hard or take a lot of time.  You just have to do it.  I know people who have been talking about investing in Bitcoin since it was at $2.  They always have a reason not to get in, but if they had just tossed $5 at it back then, maybe they would have gotten comfortable with it, invested more over the years, and would be financially free today instead of still wondering if they should invest.

It's even harder for them to throw in a little buck and see how it goes the first time. It's always easier said than done.

comments.author: Questat
comments.body: You nailed it right mate. There’s no problem with bitcoin investment especially a lot have been successful because of it, but let’s be practical here. Fiat is still the most essential thing that will help us secure our daily survival. We have to build financial security first with fiat because it’s what makes us live our present, after that we’ll proceed to secure our future retirement and that’s where bitcoin should be a crucial part. Stabilize your finances first, before we start taking risk with bitcoin and deal with its uncertainties.
